origination.corpname: University of Michigan. University Planner's Office.

did.unittitle: University Planner's Office (University of Michigan) records 1940-2014
did.abstract: The University Planner's Office oversees the master planning, site planning, and site design for the university. The records consist of correspondence, memoranda, meeting minutes, reports, architectural drawings, and photographs spanning the years 1840 to 2014.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The University Planner's Office (Donor no. 5582) makes periodic additions to the records.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, University Planner's Office (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University Planner's Office has historically reported to Plant Extension and is an offshoot of the University Architect's Office. The responsibilities of the two offices have often overlapped and their respective responsibilities for campus development and upkeep are intertwined. The office oversees master planning, site planning and site design. The University Planner's Office also manages the review of all exterior element designs including signage, furnishings, public art, and lighting.1

The University Architect's Office was established in 1957 within the Plant Service Department, with Lynn W. Fry the first person to hold the title of University Architect. In 1964 John D. Telfer, formerly the Assistant to the University Architect, became the university's first University Planner. Telfer served in this position until 1968.

As stated above, the responsibilities of the University Planner are tangential to those of the University Architect, both being the natural result of an expanding, growing university community. The University Architect's Office devotes the bulk of its time to advising and serving as liaison between architects and the university community on construction and renovation projects. The role of the University Planner's Office is akin to that of a civil engineer and is concerned with the issues that accompany campus development, including zoning, street construction, signage, landscaping, exterior lighting, and parking.
For further information regarding building projects at the University of Michigan, the researcher should also consult the records of the University Architect's Office.

arrangement.p: The records are arranged into four series: Campus Development and History, Master Planning, Properties, and Projects.

scopecontent.p: The records of the University Planner's Office consist of 48 linear feet, 72.3 GB of digital files, and one oversize volume. Records contain correspondence, memoranda, meeting minutes, reports, architectural drawings, and photographs spanning the years 1840 to 2014. The records document the role of the University Planner's Office in campus planning on the University of Michigan campuses and in conjunction with the City of Ann Arbor.

scopecontent.p: The Campus Development and History series (1840-2008, 3 linear feet and 17 GB) is divided into two subseries: Early Campus Development and Campus History.
Early Campus Development contains information regarding early campus landscaping, old plans, and various reports from the early 20th century.

did.unittitle: Old Plans, The Univ. of Michigan Ann Arbor, 1840-1966

scopecontent.p: The Campus History subseries contains compiled research from 1840 to the early 2000s. Included are clippings, Public Works Program documentation, old walking tours, photographs and slides.

scopecontent.p: The Master Planning series (1950-2009, 8.5 linear feet) is separated into five subseries: Central Campus, East Medical Campus, North Campus, Dearborn Campus, and Flint campus. The series, and each subseries, contains materials relating to the master plans of each campus, research reports, correspondence, land deeds, and photographs and slides of buildings and lands.

scopecontent.p: The Properties series (1850-2014, 24 linear feet and 41.5 GB) is divided into five subseries: Buildings by Number, Buildings by Name, Removed Buildings, Miscellaneous Properties, and Public Art. Buildings by Number, Removed Buildings, and Miscellaneous Properties are organized by differing numbering systems used by the University's Planner's Office. Each property's folder contains a historical report containing information regarding construction and press releases. Deed and gift records, photographs, slides, management, and rights information can also be found within these files.

scopecontent.p: The Projects series (1950-2008, 12.5 linear feet) generally concern issues that arise from the construction of a building or other campus development. These issues are broad-ranging and include parking lots and structures, changes in traffic patterns, exterior lighting, bicycle paths and bicycle racks, recreation areas, signage, pedestrian bridges and walkways, zoning issues, and landscaping. As the University Planner works in close contact with the University Architect, this record group also includes material concerning the numerous building projects on the three university campuses.
